thread.title: 24 arrested in Anaheim protests after off-duty cop shoots at teens on property - Salon.com
thread.title_full: 24 arrested in Anaheim protests after off-duty cop shoots at teens on property - Salon.com

author: Matthew Rozsa
title: 24 arrested in Anaheim protests after off-duty cop shoots at teens on property - Salon.com
text:
Thursday, Feb 23, 2017 6:13 PM UTC 24 arrested in Anaheim protests after off-duty cop shoots at teens on property The protests were sparked by an off-duty cop who waved his gun at teens Topics: Anaheim , police officers , Protests , Racism , Video News , News , Politics News 
More than 300 protesters took to the streets of Anaheim on Wednesday night after a video showing an off-duty police officer firing his gun during a confrontation with unarmed teenagers went viral. 
The video showed the police officer and the teenager struggling, with the officer accusing the teenager of threatening to shoot him and the kid vehemently denying it. After another teenager struck the police officer, the cop could be seen pulling out his gun and firing it into the air. 
Twenty-four protesters were arrested, according to the Los Angeles Times , after the Anaheim Police Department ordered the protesters to disperse at roughly 10 p.m. Those protesters were part of the approximately 100 protesters who remained at Palais Road and Euclid Street. Initial reports indicating that this included 10 men, eight women, three male minors and three female minors were arrested. 
The arrested protesters were allegedly near the house of the police officer responsible for the Tuesday video, whose name had not been released. The incident shown in the video occurred on the officer’s property. The Los Angeles Police Department insisting that the conflict was precipitated by the teenagers trespassing on his property, and one of the teenagers allegedly threatening to shoot the cop. Two of the teenagers were arrested, with one being booked at Orange County Juvenile Hall and the other being released to his parents. 
“Like many in the community, I’ve seen the video and I’m very concerned about what it shows,” Anaheim mayor Tom Tait said in a statement. “Anaheim is committed to a full and impartial investigation. Our city will move forward without delay.” 
Matthew Rozsa is a breaking news writer for Salon. He holds an MA in History from Rutgers University-Newark and his work has appeared in Mic, Quartz and MSNBC.
